[[SUSE Linux]] | platform = [[x86 architecture|x86]]-compatible | genre = Benchmark software | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]]/[[Open source]] | website = [http://www.vmware.com/products/vmmark/ VMmark at VMware.com] }} '''VMmark''' is a freeware [[virtual machine]] [[Benchmark (computing)|benchmark]] software suite from [[VMware]], Inc., a division of [[EMC Corporation]]. The suite measures the performance of virtualized servers while running under load on a set of physical hardware. VMmark was independently developed by VMware. == Technical overview == In order to measure the efficiency of the virtualization layer - the [[hypervisor]] - the suite must run several virtual machines (VMs) simultaneously. Each VM is configured according to a template, three of which are provided with the VMmark software. The templates mimic typical software applications found in corporate [[data center]]s, such as [[Mail transfer agent|email server]]s, [[database server]]s, and [[Web server]]s. The VMmark software collects performance statistics that are relevant to each type of application, such as commits per second for database servers, or page accesses per second for web servers.{{Cite web |url=http://www.vmware.com/pdf/vmmark_intro.pdf |title=VMmark: A Scalable Benchmark for Virtualized Systems |format=PDF |publisher=VMware, Inc. |pages=6–7 |date=2006-09-25 |accessdate=2007-10-16}} VMs are grouped into logical units called "tiles". When evaluating a system's performance, the VMmark software first calculates a score for each tile, culled from the performance statistics produced by each VM, and aggregates the per-tile scores into a final number. == Software components == VMmark uses a mixture of [[free software|free/open source]] and [[proprietary software]] in its virtual machine templates, such as [[Apache HTTP Server]] for Web servers and [[Microsoft Exchange Server]] for email servers.{{Cite web |title=VMmark System Requirements - Software Licensing Considerations |url=http://www.vmware.com/products/vmmark/requirements.html |publisher=VMware, Inc. |accessdate=2007-10-16}} == Industry reception == {{As of|2008|alt=As of May 2008}}, four computer system vendors ([[Dell|Dell Computer]], [[Hewlett-Packard]], [[IBM]], and [[Sun Microsystems]]) have submitted VMmark benchmark results to VMware.{{cite web |url=http://www.vmware.com/products/vmmark/results.html |title=VMmark Results |publisher=VMware, Inc. |accessdate=2008-05-06}} Additionally, Dell{{Cite web |title=Virtualization Performance of Dell PowerEdge Servers using the VMmark benchmark |publisher=Dell, Inc. |accessdate=2007-10-18 |format=PDF |url=http://www.dell.com/downloads/global/solutions/poweredge_vmmark_final.pdf}} and Sun{{Cite web |url=http://www.sun.com/servers/x64/x4600/VMScaling-Final3.pdf |title=Proven Virtualization Scalability With The Sun Fire X4600 Server |publisher=Sun Microsystems |accessdate=2007-10-18 |format=PDF}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}} have separately published whitepapers with VMmark results obtained on their respective computer systems. [[SWsoft]], one of VMware's competitors in the [[x86 virtualization]] market, has levied criticisms against VMmark regarding the realism of the simulated workloads and the choice of software platforms.{{Cite web |title=VMmark â comments |url=http://virtuozzoblog.swsoft.com/2007/08/vmmark-comments.html |last=Baimetov |first=Ilya |publisher=SWsoft |accessdate=2007-10-18 |date=2007-08-15}} By October 2009 that had increased to 10 vendors (HP, NEC, IBM, Unisys, Sun, Dell, [[Inspur]], Lenovo, Fujitsu and Cisco) == See also == * [[List of VMware software]] == References == {{Reflist|1}} == External links == * [http://www.vmware.com/products/vmmark/overview.html VMmark product page] - VMware, Inc. * [http://www.vmware.com/pdf/vmmark_intro.pdf VMmark white paper] - VMware, Inc. * [http://www.spec.org/specvirtualization/ Virtualization committee] - SPEC [[Category:VMware]] [[Category:Computer benchmarks]] [[Category:Virtualization software]]
